data.title: Selection in the debug console "leaks" into the code editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: OSX El Capitan 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a code file
2. Do something that will cause output into the debug console
3. Select some text in the debug console
4. Use Shift+Up to select multiple lines

Observe: the selection "leaks" into the code editor (see attached)

![screen shot 2016-08-25 at 2 04 26 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/242340/17986054/ae80b992-6acd-11e6-9563-41de57f7916c.png)

data.title: TypeScript compile errors stop being reported when multiple Index files are open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- VSCode Insiders Version: 1.5
- TypeScript Versions: 1.8.10, 2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

Open multiple tabs named Index.ts(x). Compile errors and intellisense only appear to function properly in the first tab opened. Only appears to impact files named Index.ts/Index.tsx from what I am able to reproduce reliably.

Source: https://github.com/bdoss/tsserver-bug

![bug steps](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/0pe2rgt52wnw4qu/tsserver-bug-steps.gif)

data.title: How to know User selected extension via command or just by shortcut
data.body:
Hi,
My extension "code-settings-sync" has shortcut for command to upload / download the settings.
It deletes the extensions also, When user use shortcut for any command to download the settings rather than command palatte, I dont have any way to know because i want to set a confirmation when user use shortcut instead of command palatte.

This check or feature will be nice to have.

data.title: Windows: possible to have drag overlay stick around

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode 
  Version 1.5.0-insider
  Commit 435df14a684df718c5ec523f9d674e63d1662c37
  Date 2016-08-22T08:10:56.602Z
  Shell 0.37.6
  Renderer 49.0.2623.75
  Node 5.10.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Code to a folder with lots of folders and files
2. Open 2 explorer windows and place them in front of Code leaving the tree view visible between them
3. Click and drag a folder between the 2 explorer windows and over the tree view.
4. Drag back and fourth fairly quickly watching Code gray out and return to normal.
5. Watch for it to not restore back to normal.
6. Bring Code into focus.
7. See that you cannot interact with the Code editor window.
8. The File Menu bar does continue to work.
9. Drag a file or folder back over Code to restore functionality.

Sometimes it will reproduce very nicely and other times hardly at all. I think the folder/file structure in the tree view makes a difference. I can only do this with folders and not files and the motion has to be fairly fast. As if it misses the mouse leaving the window event or something like that.

[OK]

data.title: New File improvements

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Scenario:**
- Editing a file `y.txt` inside a directory `x`
- I want to create a new file `z.txt` in directory `x`
- I am a user who likes to be efficient and loves keyboard shortcuts

**Workflows to create new files:**
1. Take over control of the mouse/trackpad, navigate to +file icon (top left next to explorer). A new file is created inside `x` and I can name it `z.txt`, then edit its contents.
2. Press `cmd+n`, which opens a new file. Now I want to save it so I press `cmd+s` and proceed to name the file, navigate to `x` directory and save. I can edit the contents before and after saving

**Problems with current workflows:**
- Method 1 of creating a new file is good, but I need to take control of the mouse/trackpad. 
- Method 2 can be done keyboard-only but is less efficient than method 1 as it requires thinking about where `x` directory is and how to find it.

**Improvement proposal:**

I am proposing the ideal workflow with the given scenario.
1. Edit the file `y.txt`, which is in `x`
2. Press `cmd+n`, editor opens new file
3. I type the file name inside the new editor tab (as file content)
4. Press `cmd+s` to save file, the editor takes the first line of the content as file name and saves it into `x`b y default
5. The first line either stays as it is or is deleted and I can go on writing the new file

data.title: WebView not scaled correctly when zooming vscode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Zoom the UI
2. Open any WebView (e.g. Extensions Details or Preview of a Markdown File)

The opened WebView is sized for a zoom, but not scaled, staying at 100%, leaving empty space in it's container.
When Zooming with the WebView being open, it is sized and scaled correctly.

data.title: Alt button conflict (toggle menu-bar & multi-select)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:45:31.680Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Hi, I'm using Code on windows and there is a little annoying conflict with the "Alt" button when im on full screen, you see Alt is the button used for multi-selection and also for toggling the menu bar, means the menu bar keeps appearing every time i try to multi-select, which causes the code to scroll down a line or two in a very annoying way

I guess a good solution would be giving us the option to assign another button for toggling the menu bar instead of Alt.

thank you.

data.title: Issues on SAVE

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:45:31.680Z)
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 x64

From at least two releases of Visual Studio Code, I have issues with the SAVE menu item.
I generally work with several tabs opened and when I save the file of the current tab, the tab title still blinking, and the save is not done while I'm not selecting another tab.
But most of the time, the content of the saved tab is copied on the new displayed tab. 
There is a second issue : if by mistake, I also do save in the new tab (after the content has been changed or replaced) the 'undo' precess doesn't works!

Steps to Reproduce:
1. modify the code ot the selected tab
2. Do save -> tab title is blinking
3. Go to another tab -> the file of the previous tab is saved
4. The content of the saved tab is copied into the new current tab.

data.title: OutputChannels show up as active editor
Errors from an extension appear in Output instead of JS console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1607

I'm using an extension that outputs errors fairly frequently (https://github.com/vshaxe/vshaxe). For some reason, these errors go the Output panel for me in a `Haxe` channel:

![](http://i.imgur.com/jj4CjI7.png)

This is quite strange, because for everybody else using this extension I've talked to, these errors go to the JS console of the developer tools. This is also the case on my Windows 7 laptop, where I did a clean install of VSCode + the extension (same versions) for testing:

![](http://i.imgur.com/4o0njo8.png)

What makes this especially annoying is that when I hide the Output panel, it pops back up automatically when a new error appears and _steals focus_.

I have tried the following steps to solve the issue on my Win10 PC (to no avail):
- reinstall VSCode
- remove all extensions except vshaxe
- delete `%AppData%/Code`
- start VSCode from the command line with `code --user-data-dir=<some-random-directory>`

The only reasonable explanation I have is that _something_ must be different about my VSCode installation, maybe some leftover configuration from earlier VSCode versions or _anything_ that would make it behave differently in this regard. Are there other places where VSCode stores configs?

data.title: Eslint error when opening a javascript file: Failed to load plugin jsx-a11y: Cannot find module 'eslint-plugin-jsx-a11y'

I have installed the ESLint extension.

{

data.title: Need HTML Matching Keystroke
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: Windows 10

In HTML editor, need a keyboard mapping that allows you to jump to the matching tag.  I am aware that if you place the cursor on a tag, the matching tag is highlighted; but in a div that may sufficiently long as to not be visible on the screen, it would be useful to quickly jump to the matching tag.

It would also be extremely useful to have a keyboard mapping that selects the entire current block.  e.g., Ctrl+B within a div selects the entire div.  This facilitates quickly re-arranging elements within a document without visually hunting for the beginning/ending tags of an element.  

Thank you for this great editor and providing it as free & open source!

data.title: Auto show/hide terminal window [Feature Req]

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Similar to behavior in Visual Studio, is there a way we could get the terminal to show/hide automatically? Leaving some sort of tab at the bottom of the screen?

It opens when:
1. User mouses over the tab 
2. Something is written to the terminal

It hides when:
1. User clicks outside of the open terminal window.
2. The terminal has not been written to within a set period of ~10 seconds.

Ex: I'm working on an Angular 2 application using the angular-cli build tool. When I'm writing code or clicking through the UI I don't particularly care about what's displaying in the terminal. But as soon as I save my changes and the build process starts, I DO want to quickly see what the current state of the build is. So after saving a file, when the CLI tool starts writing to the terminal, it would pop-up from the bottom, and as long as my mouse isn't hovering over it, it will hide again after several seconds of inactivity.

data.title: issue accessing (writing?) to file from disk when open in vscode on macosx

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: MacOSX

Steps to Reproduce:

Problem 1: VSCode gets into a very tight loop saving an open file.
It seems, if you save a file from VSCode and then make a modification to the same file from the shell, while the file is open in VSCode, it causes VSCode to go into a loop - saving the file continuously. 
1. Open a file in VSCode (e.g. package.json )
2. Remove a package from dependencies.
3. Save the file. 
4. Very quickly after (i tried 1-2 seconds after), 'npm install the_same_pkg -S' 

It causes the package.json tab in VSCode to go into a loop, toggling between the modified "circle" and close "x" in very quick succession.

The only way to recover seems to be to close the tab - at which point VSCode complains that 
there are unsaved changes. I've tried saving and not saving and not saving the perceived changes
from VScodes point-of-view. In either case, the npm modifications to package.json are lost. 

Killing the tab post modification-save from VSCode and then opening the file in a new tab does not seem to cause the same issue.

Here is an example of what I'm talking about : The code is correctly formated and functional, and it actually have a correct highlight on other editors like atom for example). I'm using the dark+ theme and I've already tried to install some other themes and adding highlight snippets to see if they made a difference but the problem was still here. Hope you can help

data.title: Shortcut improvements
data.body:
Is it possible to define shortcuts like:
- `cmd+k cmd+u` (convert selection to uppercase)
- `cmd+k cmd+l` (convert selection to lowercase)
- `cmd+l` when selected multiple lines, create a cursor at the end of each line
- `ctrl+cmd+up(arrow)` move selection up/down

What would be the best way to implement these, and if you don't mind I can make a PR for this?

data.title: Efficient tab switching workflow
data.body:
I came to Code from TextMate and Sublime world. In those editors, you use CMD+[1-9] to switch between open tabs.

How do you efficiently switch between tabs in Code? It seems a little counter intuitive (for me) for cmd+2 to open a split screen.

Please note i am not criticising how it is in VSCode. I get that most users of Code have maybe larger screens and switch between split screens often. However different users work differently, so I am curious about the reasons behind this approach and also see if there's any way I can configure the editor to open tabs using cmd+num shortcuts.

Thanks!

data.title: Feature request: Add workspace specific snippets
data.body:
It would be great if we could add project specific snippets. This way common requires or api snippets can be use across the team for a given project.

Thank you
